intro: Psoralea repens, commonly known as the creeping psoralea, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its slender, prostrate stems that spread along the ground. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in dense spikes, and its leaves are trifoliate, consisting of three oval-shaped leaflets. It thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid regions. Psoralea repens is also known for its ability to fix nitrogen, contributing to soil fertility in its native habitat.
